content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. For time <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, people arrive at a venue for an outdoor concert at a rate modeled by the function <math alttext="A"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></math> defined by <math alttext="A, of t equals, 0.3 times the sine of, open parenthesis, 1.9 t, close parenthesis, plus, 0.3 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, 0.6 t, close parenthesis, plus 1.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.9</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.6</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For time <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, no one leaves the venue, and for time <math alttext="1 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, people leave the venue at a rate modeled by the function <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="L of t equals, 0.2 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, 1.9 t, close parenthesis, plus, 0.2 times sine t, plus 0.8"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.9</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="A, of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in hundreds of people per hour, and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. The number of people at the venue, in hundreds, at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hours is given by <math alttext="P of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) At time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, there are 6 hundred people at the venue. Write an equation for the locally linear approximation of <math alttext="P"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math> at <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and use it to approximate the number of people at the venue at time <math alttext="t equals 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. For time <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, people arrive at a venue for an outdoor concert at a rate modeled by the function <math alttext="A"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></math> defined by <math alttext="A, of t equals, 0.3 times the sine of, open parenthesis, 1.9 t, close parenthesis, plus, 0.3 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, 0.6 t, close parenthesis, plus 1.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.9</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.6</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For time <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, no one leaves the venue, and for time <math alttext="1 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, people leave the venue at a rate modeled by the function <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="L of t equals, 0.2 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, 1.9 t, close parenthesis, plus, 0.2 times sine t, plus 0.8"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.9</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="A, of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in hundreds of people per hour, and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. The number of people at the venue, in hundreds, at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hours is given by <math alttext="P of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) At time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, there are 6 hundred people at the venue. Write an equation for the locally linear approximation of <math alttext="P"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math> at <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and use it to approximate the number of people at the venue at time <math alttext="t equals 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find <math alttext="P double prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="P double prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(c) Is there a time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="1 less than t, less than 8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which the rate of change of the number of people at the venue changes from negative to positive? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) A rectangular “standing-only” section at the venue changes size as <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increases in order to manage the flow of people. Let <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the length, in feet, of the section, and let <math alttext="y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the width, in feet, of the section. The length of the section is increasing at a rate of 6 feet per hour, and the width of the section is decreasing at a rate of 3 feet per hour. What is the rate of change of the area of the section with respect to time when <math alttext="x equals 16"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Indicate units of measure.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
